questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling out of bed. He ate dinner an hour earlier and had been asleep for 30 minutes when his mother heard him fall off the bed onto a hardwood floor. She checked his room and found him unconscious on the floor with a blue discoloration around his lips that resolved after a few seconds. He regained consciousness after a few minutes but seemed sleepier than normal. He has slowly become more awake over the past 30 minutes and is now alert and interactive, but he does not remember anything about the event. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Generalized seizures This patient had an episode of loss of consciousness, a history of falling from bed, cyanosis around lips, and no memory about these events associated with a period of sleepiness afterward , which strongly suggests an epileptic seizure.

Highyeild:

Classification of Seizures: Focal Onset having intact or impaired awareness motor or nonmotor onset evolve from focal to bilateral tonic-clonic Generalized Onset Motor Tonic-clonic Other motor Atonic Myoclonic Nonmotor Absence Unknown Onset Motor Nonmotor Unclassified

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Narcolepsy -is a disorder characterized by excessive sleepiness , cataplexy , hypnagogic hallucinations, and sleep paralysis, n one of which are present in this child. Option: C. Breath-holding spells - occur in children aged 6 months to 6 years and present with either cyanosis or pallor following an upsetting event or minor injury. Patients typically recover without any postictal period of sleepiness and confusion. Option: D.Vasovagal syncope - postictal phase of sleepiness and confusion for minutes to hours, does not occur.

questions.text: 6-year-old Rinku is brought for evaluation of blank spells. Her teacher reports that the child seems to have trouble concentrating during class and often has episodes of staring into space. The patient is otherwise healthy and has been meeting developmental milestones. There is no history of trauma, infection, or problems at birth. She has an uncle with epilepsy, On examination, the child is alert with normal vital signs Neurologic examination is normal. Which of the following features of this patient's episodes would be most consistent with a diagnosis of absence seizures?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eyelid fluttering

Highyeild:

Absence seizures are brief, generalized seizures characterized by a sudden impairment of consciousness in children aged 4-10. Absence seizures may be accompanied by simple automatisms (eg, eyelid fluttering, lip smacking) but not more complex motor events . Patients generally are unaware that a seizure has occurred and do not remember what happened during it. The events are often first noticed by teachers and are frequently mistaken for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or normal childhood staring spells. 30% → GTCs/Myoclonic epilepsy 80% remission in adulthood Blank /vacant stare- seconds Unawareness → during ictal → nonresponsive Neuro examination/MRI- normal One of the ways to elicit and document absence seizure is hyperventilation. EEG- 3 spikes wave pattern EEG showing 3 per second (3Hz) spike and wave discharges typical of absence epilepsy Treatment: Ethosuximide Valproate

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. benign staring spells - Sleepiness due to inattention are seen in healthy children and in those with ADHD and can be mistaken for absence seizures . However, these benign staring spells typically occur only when children are bored (eg, in the classroom), and children usually can be redirected by calling their name or tactile stimulation. Option: C.Postural tone is preserved with absence seizures . Loss of postural tone should raise concern for other generalized seizures or syncopal events (eg, cardiac arrhythmia) Option: D.Prolonged impairment of consciousness >2 minutes- is inconsistent with typical absence seizures. Alternate seizure etiologies (eg, focal seizure with impairment of consciousness, generalized seizure) should be sought for patients with prolonged episodes

questions.text: 29-year-old Mrs. Mehta comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. Five years ago, she experienced an unprovoked generalized tonic¬ clonic seizure. At that time, phenytoin was prescribed, and the patient has been on a stable dose since. She has not experienced seizure recurrence. The MRI brain was normal at the initial episode. She is considering becoming pregnant. Blood pressure is 123/72 mm Hg and pulse is 75/min. Neurologic examination is unremarkable. The serum phenytoin level is 11 mcg/ml (therapeutic range, 10-20 mcg/ml). EEG is normal. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Slowly taper and discontinue phenytoin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Slowly taper and discontinue phenytoin Discontinuing phenytoin in this patient who has a history of unprovoked seizure but has been seizure free for 5 years is a reasonable consideration. Given her lack of identifiable brain disease, normal EEG, absence of familial epilepsy, and positive initial response to therapy , this patient is at low risk for seizure recurrence . In addition, phenytoin is a known teratogen capable of causing fetal hydantoin syndrome . Given its known teratogenicity , phenytoin should be discontinued in women of reproductive age who are considering becoming pregnant and have a low risk of seizure recurrence . personalized slow taper is indicated as rapid withdrawal may result in seizure recurrence.

Highyeild:

WHEN TO DISCONTINUE THERAPY Overall, ~50–60% of patients who have their seizures completely controlled with antiseizure drugs can eventually discontinue therapy. The following patient profile yields the greatest chance of remaining seizure free after drug withdrawal: Complete medical control of seizures for 1–5 years Single seizure type, normal neurologic examination, including intelligence No family history of epilepsy Normal EEG. The appropriate seizure-free interval Unknown depends on the form of epilepsy Generalized seizures have a better prognosis than focal seizures whether or not the causal factor is still present Resection of a brain tumor causing seizures Attempt withdrawal of therapy After 2 years in a patient who meets all of the above criteria Motivated to discontinue medication Understands the potential risks and benefits. Reduce the dose of the drug gradually over 2–3 months. Most recurrences occur in the first 3 months after discontinuing therapy Patients should be advised to avoid potentially dangerous situations such as driving or swimming during this period Up to 20% of seizure-free patients who discontinue antiseizure medications but then have a recurrent seizure may not regain full control when these medications are resumed.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Discontinue phenytoin now-Rapid withdrawal may result in seizure recurrence. Option: B. Increase phenytoin dose -Increasing the dose of phenytoin in this patient who has a 5-year seizure-free period and is considering becoming pregnant is inappropriate. Option: D. Switch to valproate- Like phenytoin, valproic acid is teratogenic .

Extraedge:

Preconception management of epilepsy Confirm the epilepsy diagnosis Start folic acid 1 to 5 mg/day Use the most effective Antiepileptic medication at the lowest dose Avoid valproate, topiramate, and phenobarbital Establish baseline serum drug concentration. Safe Antiepileptics in Pregnancy- Oxcarbazepine Lamotrigine Levetiracetam

questions.text: 22-year-old Mr.Kapoor is brought to the emergency dept. 40 minutes after having a first-time generalized tonic-clonic seizure. According to his mother, the patient exhibited shaking for 5 minutes. He has never had a seizure previously or any episodes of jerking, staring, confusion, or memory loss. He has had no recent illness and has no history of neurological problems. Birth and development were normal. There is no family history of seizures or epilepsy. He takes no medication and does not use illicit drugs. On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Neurological examinations are unremarkable. Results of laboratory studies show a normal CBC and comprehensive metabolic panel and a negative urine drug screen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Head CT Neuroimaging is indicated in all patients with first-time seizures to rapidly exclude conditions requiring emergent intervention , including hemorrhage. Head CT is the most appropriate initial study because it typically is readily available in most emergency departments and can be performed rapidly. The patient will later require both MRI and electroencephalography , but CT is the best initial study.

Intravenous levetiracetam - and other anti-epileptic drugs are not recommended for first-time seizures until the results of further testing, such as CT head, brain MRI, EEG is known as the recurrence risk of seizures can be He had an unprovoked seizure but does not meet the criteria for the diagnosis of epilepsy . Option: C. Intravenous lorazepam-not indicated as seizure activity was not ongoing and the patient has recovered completely and has normal findings on clinical examination. Option: D. Lumbar puncture -In adults lumbar puncture is appropriate when meningitis is clinically suspected (In the presence of neck stiffness , altered mental status, or fever ) or when a patient has symptoms highly suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage or in conjunction with normal non-contrast head CT It otherwise is not indicated after a seizure in adults .

questions.text: 23-year-old Mrs. Sinha is brought to the emergency department after a seizure episode. The seizure occurred at work and was not preceded by any prodromal symptoms or aura. The patient's co-workers reported that she became unresponsive with generalized tonic-clonic movements lasting 1-2 minutes followed by several minutes of confusion. She experienced urinary incontinence but no tongue biting. The patient has no medical problems and takes no prescription medications. She has no prior head trauma and no family history of epilepsy. Vital signs and neurologic examination are normal. Serum Labs are unremarkable. A non-contrast head CT scan is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: MRI of the brain with seizure protocol

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Check urine drug screen The initial diagnostic evaluation of a first-time seizure in an adult is aimed at excluding metabolic (eg, hypoglycemia, electrolyte disturbances) and toxic (eg, amphetamine use, benzodiazepine/alcohol withdrawal) causes . Basic laboratory tests typically include serum electrolytes , glucose , calcium , magnesium, complete blood count , renal function tests, liver function tests, and a toxicology screen . In addition to laboratory screening, ECG should be obtained in patients with loss of consciousness to evaluate for possible underlying arrhythmia.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Routine EEG - is useful for risk-stratifying patients after a first-time seizure once metabolic and toxic etiologies have been excluded . The presence of epileptiform activity on an EEG indicates a higher risk of seizure recurrence and therefore may justify the need to start anti-epileptic therapy. Option: B. MRI of the brain with seizure protocol- Once metabolic and toxic etiologies are excluded as the cause of the seizure, most patients require neuroimaging (eg, brain MRI or CT scan) to evaluate for structural brain abnormalities (eg , tumor , stroke, mesial t emporal sclerosis )that may serve as a seizure focus. Option: D.Valproic acid- is generally avoided in young women of reproductive age as it may cause congenital anomalies (eg, neural tube defects) during pregnancy . It is also premature to start the patient on any anti-epileptic therapy at this time as she may have had a provoked seizure due to substance abuse.

Drug withdrawal that can cause seizure Alcohol Baclofen Barbiturates (short-acting) Benzodiazepines (short-acting) Zolpidem Drugs of abuse that can cause seizure Amphetamine Cocaine Phencyclidine Methylphenidate Flumazenil-In benzodiazepine-dependent patients

questions.text: 19-year-old Tina is brought to the emergency department by her mother after an episode of loss of consciousness. The girl was taking a shower when her mother heard her fall. By the time the mother unlocked the bathroom door, the girl was lying on the bathroom floor and not responding to questions. The patient recently broke up with her boyfriend and has been under a lot of stress at college. She has been sleeping poorly. Blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 13/min. After 20 minutes in the emergency department, the patient begins to wake up and respond to external stimuli. She gives her correct name but is disoriented to time and place. Pupils are symmetric and reactive to light, Fingerstick glucose level is 100 mg/dl following examination or laboratory findings is most likely to be seen in this patient.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tongue laceration Sudden loss of consciousness (LOC) , loss of postural tone , and delayed return to baseline mental status should raise suspicion for seizure (eg, generalized tonic-clonic). Some patients may experience an aura (eg, olfactory hallucination ) prior to the seizure and/or lateral tongue lacerations during the event. Compared to other etiologies of Sudden loss of consciousness (LOC) , generalized seizures almost always have a delayed return to baseline neurologic functioning due to a postictal state of transient confusion , lethargy , and/or focal neurologic deficits.

Seizure Syncope Posture at onset Any posture Erect Immediate precipitating factor Absent Emotional stress Valsalva History of cardiac problem Premonitory symptoms None or Aura (e,g., odd odor) Tiredness Nausea Diaphoresis Tunneling of vision Facial appearance during event Cyanosis Frothing at mouth Pallor ++ Duration of tonic or clonic movements 30-60 sec Never crosses 15-sec Transition to unconsciousness Minutes Gradual over seconds Duration of unconsciousness Minutes Seconds Disorientation and sleepiness minutes-hours <5 min Aching of muscles after event Often Sometimes Biting of tongue Sometimes Rarely Incontinence Sometimes Sometimes Headache Sometimes Rarely

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Acetaminophen toxicity - causes a predictable sequence of nausea/vomiting , right upper quadrant pain with elevation of liver enzymes and potential liver failure and death . Seizures are not typical. Option: B.Orthostatic hypotension - is characterized by a significant drop in blood pressure after shifting from a lying to a standing Causes include intravascular volume depletion (due to blood loss or dehydration) and medication-related autonomic instability (eg, beta blockers). Orthostatic hypotension patients will not be disoriented for such a long time. Option: D.Pulsus paradoxus -refers to a fall in systemic blood pressure >10 mm Hg during normal inspiration . It is a common finding in patients with cardiac tamponade , which can present with syncope but also with tachycardia, hypotension , and elevated jugular venous pressure . This patient’s vitals are normal so this option is excluded.

Extraedge:

Syncope is a transient loss of consciousness (LOC) with loss of postural tone followed by an immediate spontaneous return to baseline neurologic function . The most common cause of syncope is vasovagal syncope , which may be preceded by a prodrome of nausea, warmth, light-headedness , diaphoresis, Pallor, and weak pulses (due to vagus nerve activation) strongly suggest syncope.

questions.text: 21-year-old Mr. Patil is evaluated in the emergency department for persistent convulsive status epilepticus that began 30 minutes before his arrival. An airway has been secured, and he has received Intravenous glucose, thiamine, and 2 doses of Intravenous lorazepam. After receiving the second dose of lorazepam he continues shaking for another 5 minutes. The patient is allergic to phenytoin. On physical examination temperature is normal, and blood pressure is 155/89 Hg. The pulse rate is 108/ min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation on the nasal cannula is 97%. The pupils are reactive but he remains comatose. The results of urine drug screens are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Valproic acid The patient should now receive valproic acid. He is in generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE) as he has persistent tonic-clonic activity with impaired mental status lasting longer than 5 minutes with impaired consciousness(comatose) between the episodes Intravenous lorazepam, one of the first line agents for the initial treatment of convulsive status epilepticus have been given and the patient is not responding. Phenytoin , a longer-acting seizure drug, should then be administered or fosphenytoin . As the patient is allergic to phenytoin, Valproic acid can be administered as an alternative to phenytoin or fosphenytoin .

Highyeild:

Status epilepticus Continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness in the interictal period. Subtypes Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE) Persistent, generalized electrographic seizures, coma, and tonic-clonic movements Nonconvulsive status epilepticus Persistent absence seizures Persistent focal seizures with confusion or partially impaired consciousness Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE) Duration of seizures Prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy. Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE) This is typically when seizures last beyond 5 min. Causes of GCSE - Anticonvulsant withdrawal Noncompliance metabolic disturbances drug toxicity CNS infection CNS tumors Refractory epilepsy Head trauma. GCSE Treatment Emergency and must be treated immediately, GCSE → Cardiorespiratory dysfunction , hyperthermia, and metabolic derangements → Irreversible neuronal injury . First step Airway management Any acute cardiorespiratory problems Hyperthermia Perform a brief medical and neurologic examination Establish venous access Send samples for laboratory studies Identify metabolic abnormalities. Anticonvulsant therapy should then begin without delay A treatment approach is shown in the image below. Pharmacologic treatment of generalized tonic-clonic status epilepticus (SE) in adults. CLZ, clonazepam; ECT, electroconvulsive therapy; LCM, lacosamide; LEV, levetiracetam; LZP, lorazepam; MDZ, midazolam; PGB, pregabalin; PHT, phenytoin or fosphenytoin; PRO, propofol, PTB, pentobarbital; RNS, responsive neurostimulation; rTMS, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation; THP, thiopental; TPM, topiramate; VNS, vagus nerve stimulation; VPA, valproic acid. (Data from AO Rossetti, DH Lowenstein: Management of refractory status epilepticus in adults: still more questions than answers. Lancet Neurol 10:922, 2011.) Treatment of nonconvulsive status epilepticus - Less urgent than GCSE because the ongoing seizures are not accompanied by the severe metabolic disturbances seen with GCSE . However, evidence suggests that Nonconvulsive status epilepticus , especially that caused by ongoing, focal seizure activity , is associated with cellular injury in the region of the seizure focus ; therefore, this condition should be treated as promptly as possible using the general approach described for GCSE.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Brain MRI - status epilepticus is usually diagnosed clinically . Obtaining an MRI of the brain is an unnecessarily time-consuming process and would delay treatment. Option: C. Electroencephalogram-Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE) is obvious in this patient having overt seizures . The EEG is performed to rule out ongoing status epilepticus in Patients who stopped having an overt seizure and are still comatose OR have been paralyzed with neuromuscular blockade. Option: D. Lacosamide -which is available Intravenously sometimes is considered in the management of convulsive status epilepticus . However, evidence is insufficient to recommend it as a part of the standard guidelines for the initial treatment of generalized status epilepticus , which makes it inappropriate for this patient.

questions.text: Convulsive seizures during pregnancy can have all of the following effects on the developing fetus? A) Fetal bradycardia and asphyxia B) Child has increased risk of epilepsy C) Blunt trauma to the fetus D) Large for gestational age Select the correct answer from given below code:
questions.correct_answer: A. A, B, C are correct
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A, B, C are correct Convulsive seizures during pregnancy can have significant effects on the fetus and are felt to be of higher risk than antiepileptic medications.

Highyeild:

Complications of Convulsive seizures during pregnancy- Maternal trauma Foetus- Can be injured with blunt trauma Placental abruption Bradycardia and asphyxia during and after a seizure. Repeated convulsive seizures Miscarriage Stillbirth Prematurity Small for gestational age Increased risk of major malformations. A single uncomplicated seizure during the first trimester does not seem to have an increased risk for fetal malformations . Children with epileptic mothers not on medications during pregnancy have twice the risk of developing epilepsy compared with children born to epileptic mothers well controlled on medications.

questions.text: A 15-month-old girl is brought to the emergency room by her mother because of concern about seizures. The patient had been reaching milestones until 3 months ago when she seemed to have regression. At 6 months old, she had a single seizure associated with a fever. Magnetic resonance imaging and EEG at the time were unremarkable. Today, the patient developed recurrent clonic episodes in the absence of a fever. The mother has noted quick jerking movements of both arms over the last several weeks. Neurological examination revealed myoclonic jerks but was otherwise non-focal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dravet syndrome Of the various options, this patient most likely has Dravet syndrome, as she had 1 episode of febrile seizure at<1 yr of age, followed by developmental milestone regression and myoclonic seizure recurrence.

Highyeild:

Dravet syndrome/Severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy: This comes from a mutation affecting the SCN1A gene . Initially, children develop normally until they present with a febrile seizure under the age of 1 year . Over the course of months they continue to have milestone regression and develop multiple seizure types , including myoclonic seizures, atonic seizures, absence seizures, and complex partial seizures . Seizures may be exacerbated by carbamazepine or lamotrigine. An initially normal EEG can change to hypsarrhythmia or even multifocal slow spike and wave. Drug of choice is Valproate.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A.Ohtahara syndrome is also known as early myoclonic encephalopathy and involves focal myoclonus that shifts from one region to the next in the first 3 months of life with spasms developing later in the disorder. The neurological examination is abnormal at birth with hypotonia , possible seizures, and an abnormal EEG. Option: C.Benign familial neonatal epilepsy is a dominantly inherited disorder with a mutation in voltage-gated potassium channels. This leads to seizures on the second or third day of life but remits by 6 months of age. The child develops normally despite these seizures. Option: D.Lennox-Gastaut syndrome- typically develops between the ages of 3 and 5 , EEG shows slow (<3 Hz) spike-and-wave discharges and involves multiple seizure types along with cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: 27-year-old Mrs. Sharma is evaluated in the emergency department after a sudden first-time episode of loss of consciousness while standing in line to board a tour bus. She had tunnel vision and palpitations, after which she lost consciousness and fell. According to her father, who witnessed the episode, she was limp and unconscious for appropriately 10 seconds, during which time she displayed intermittent twitching of all four limbs with the limbs shaking independently at separate times. After the patient regained consciousness she was confused about why she was on the ground but answered questions appropriately and was oriented to self and place. All physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Convulsive syncope This patient's tunnel vision , palpitations , short duration of loss of consciousness (< 1 min), Brief period ( 10 sec ) of Asynchronous(all 4 limbs shaking independently ) , Convulsive motor activity and immediate and complete neurologic recovery are typical of syncope .

Highyeild:

Syncope: Provoked by acute pain emotional stress immediately after arising from the lying or sitting position. Clinical feature: A stereotyped transition from consciousness to unconsciousness tiredness, sweating, nausea, and tunneling of vision , and they experience a relatively brief loss of consciousness . Headache or incontinence usually suggests a seizure but may on occasion also occur with syncope. A brief period (i.e., 1–10 s) of convulsive motor activity is frequently seen immediately at the onset of a syncopal episode, especially if the patient remains in an upright posture after fainting (e.g., in a dentist’s chair) and therefore has a sustained decrease in cerebral perfusion. Rarely, a syncopal episode can induce a full tonic-clonic seizure. In such cases, the evaluation must focus on both the cause of the syncopal event as well as the possibility that the patient has a propensity for recurrent seizures. Postictal symptoms can be very helpful when differentiating convulsive syncope from seizure, as confusion and disorientation are typically much less prominent following syncope.

Atonic seizures - can be associated with falling and brief loss of consciousness with decreased tone but their duration is much briefer (a few seconds only) than that of syncope and they usually do not have warning symptoms such as tunnel vision or palpitations. Option: C. Generalized tonic-clonic seizures have increased tone at the onset ( tonic phase ) followed by rhythmic, synchronous jerking of all limbs ( clonic phase ) typically for more than 1 minute . These seizures are followed by confusion and lethargy. This patient's seizures , especially her normal neurologic state after regaining consciousness, do not match this description. Option: D. Myoclonic seizures - are very brief , typically lasting less than 1 second, and usually involve synchronous limb jerking (all limbs shaking together at the same time). The duration of this patient’s seizures and her asynchronous limb jerking , are not consistent with myoclonic seizure.
